name: Hardcoded API Key
description: API keys, passwords, or tokens hardcoded in source code

easy: Look for variables named API_KEY, SECRET, TOKEN, or PASSWORD
Check for long alphanumeric strings that look like keys
Search for strings starting with 'sk-', 'pk-', or similar prefixes
hard: Check how external services are authenticated

educationalContent.analogy: Hardcoding secrets is like writing your bank PIN on your forehead - everyone can see it, and it's really hard to change!
educationalContent.realWorldImpact: In 2022, Uber paid $148 million in fines partly due to exposed credentials. GitHub bots scan for exposed keys 24/7 and can find them within minutes of being committed.
educationalContent.preventionTip: Always use environment variables for secrets. Store them in .env files (never committed to git) and access them via import.meta.env in Vite or process.env in Node.js.

awsServices.name: AWS Secrets Manager
awsServices.description: Securely store, rotate, and manage API keys, database credentials, and other secrets with automatic rotation and fine-grained access control
awsServices.useCase: Store your API_KEY in Secrets Manager and retrieve it at runtime using the AWS SDK. Secrets Manager can automatically rotate credentials for RDS, Redshift, and DocumentDB.

awsServices.name: AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store
awsServices.description: Centralized store for configuration data and secrets with encryption at rest using AWS KMS
awsServices.useCase: Store application configuration and secrets as parameters. Use SecureString type for sensitive data. Free for standard parameters, cost-effective for large-scale deployments.

awsServices.name: AWS Key Management Service (KMS)
awsServices.description: Create and control encryption keys used to encrypt your data across AWS services
awsServices.useCase: Encrypt secrets at rest in your application. KMS integrates with Secrets Manager and Parameter Store to provide envelope encryption for your sensitive data.
